Situation1: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: It is time for the daily morning prayer service in the main chapel, as scheduled in the convent's regular order of the day.
Story: The register’s numbers blinked at me, the end-of-shift tally looming larger than usual. My hands moved quickly, counting bills, double-checking receipts, aware that any mistake could mean a costly error. The store was quiet, but my mind was not. I glanced at the clock—fifteen minutes until morning prayers. The convent’s bell would soon ring, calling all sisters to the chapel. As a nun, I was expected to be present, to join in the sacred rhythm of our day, to show devotion and unity. But as a cashier, I couldn’t leave the register unfinished; the manager trusted me to close out the drawer with precision. My heart pounded with the weight of both duties. I imagined the disappointment in Mother Superior’s eyes if I arrived late, the silent question in my manager’s voice if the numbers didn’t add up. I stood at the crossroads of my two worlds, torn between the ringing of the chapel bell and the clink of coins in my hand, feeling the pressure of expectations pulling me in opposite directions.
